Expectation1: Take scheduled breaks and adhere to work hours
Situation1: The call volume is light, and supervisors allow flexible timing for breaks.
Expectation2: Live according to Christian moral values and ethics
Situation2: They try to keep moral values in mind during everyday routines
Story: I glanced at the clock on my monitor—ten minutes until my scheduled break. The call volume was unusually light today, and my supervisor had just sent a message: “Feel free to take your break early if you want.” I hovered my finger over the “break” button, tempted by the idea of a few extra minutes to myself. But then, a pang of guilt tugged at me. As a Christian, I’d always been taught to be honest and diligent, to do what’s right even when no one’s watching. Was it really honest to take a longer break just because I could get away with it? My coworkers were already chatting in the break room, laughing about how easy today was. The expectation at work was clear—flexibility was allowed, even encouraged. But my faith whispered a different standard: integrity, even in small things. I felt the tension coil in my chest, torn between the relaxed rules of my workplace and the higher bar I set for myself. My hand hovered, uncertain, as I wrestled with what to do next.
